qas.question: In Acts 24, what is another word that Christians are called?
What was Jesus called since he was from Nazareth?
What is another Hebrew term for Nazarenes?
What is another term for Christians which appears in the Old Testament?
In which book of the Old Testament does Tertullus use the term Nazarenes to refer to Christians?
In which book of the New Testament does Marcion refer to Christians as Nazarenes as?
In which book of the New Testament does Tertullus refer to Christians as Babylonian Talmuds?
In which book of the New Testament are Nazarenes referred to as Eusebius records?

context: Another term for Christians which appears in the New Testament is "<a0_0><b4_0>Nazarenes<b4_0/><a0_0/>" which is used by the Jewish lawyer Tertullus in <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0><b8_0>Acts<b8_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/> 24. Tertullian (Against Marcion 4:8) records that "the Jews call us Nazarenes," while around 331 AD Eusebius records that Christ was called a <a1_0>Nazoraean<a1_0/> from the name Nazareth, and that in earlier centuries "Christians," were once called "Nazarenes." The Hebrew equivalent of "Nazarenes", <a2_0>Notzrim<a2_0/>, occurs in the Babylonian Talmud, and is still the <a3_0>modern Israeli Hebrew<a3_0/> term for Christian.
